conclusion: Temperature at State A, \( T_A = -73^\circ C = 200 \, \text{K} \) (since \( T(K) = T(^\circ C) + 273 \)).
Use the ideal gas law at standard conditions: \( V_m = 22.4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \) per mole at 1 atm and 273 K.

premise: Volume at State A, \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \). Use the ideal gas law at standard conditions: \( V_m = 22.4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \) per mole at 1 atm and 273 K.
conclusion: Calculate the number of moles: \( n = \frac{V_A}{V_m} = \frac{1 \times 10^{-3}}{22.4 \times 10^{-3}} \approx 0.0446 \, \text{moles} \).
Given change in internal energy from A to C, \( \Delta U = 200 \, \text{J} \).

premise: Process A to B: Isothermal expansion (no change in internal energy, \( \Delta U_{AB} = 0 \)).
conclusion: For A to B: \( \Delta U_{AB} = 0 \implies Q_{AB} = W_{AB} \).

premise: Process B to C: Isochoric process (volume constant, no work done, \( W_{BC} = 0 \)).
conclusion: For B to C: \( \Delta U_{BC} = Q_{BC} \).
Use the first law of thermodynamics: \( \Delta U = Q - W \).
Calculate work done A to B: \( W_{AB} = 0.0446 \times 8.314 \times 200 \times \ln\left(\frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{1 \times 10^{-3}}\right) \approx 240 \, \text{J} \).

premise: Given change in internal energy from A to C, \( \Delta U = 200 \, \text{J} \). For B to C: \( \Delta U_{BC} = Q_{BC} \).
conclusion: Heat added B to C: \( \Delta U_{BC} = 200 \, \text{J} = Q_{BC} \).
